video.title: Alone in the Dark | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text: Second Wind
[Intro Music]

Yeah, yeah. &quot;Ooh, Yahtzee, where&#39;s Final 
Fantasy Rebirth?&quot; &quot;Where&#39;s Dragon&#39;s Dogma 2,

Yahtzee?&quot; &quot;Yahtzee, what&#39;s this strange lump on 
the back of my neck?&quot; Look, I&#39;m not a fucking

vending machine that dispenses videos when you 
load creme eggs into the slot. I&#39;m also not a skin

specialist but that looks like an epidermoid cyst 
to me. I&#39;ve been away. I was at DC filming DND,

then I was at SF filming GDC, now I&#39;m in dire need 
of some TLC at the YMCA but I did manage to play

through the obligingly brief Alone in the Dark. 
A new addition to the IP that somehow managed to

become bankable while sidestepping the usual 
requisite of having at least one half decent

game attached to it. The original was a pioneer, 
yes, arguably the first 3D survival horror, but

in retrospect the characters all look like aborted 
lego projects on a clashing rug and animate like

they&#39;re trying to sneak across the moving walkway 
at the airport with sticks of butter strapped to

their feet. Alone In The Dark: New Nightmare in 
the PS1 era was probably the best if only because

it was smart enough to just rip off Resident Evil 
the whole way, then there was that creatively

spirited but unwittingly camp PS3-era revival and 
finally Alone in the Dark: Illumination, which was

a half square of crinkly inexpensive toilet paper 
to a long-neglected and dried out dingleberry.

So maybe in the name of clearing the slate 
a remake of the first game is just what the

IP needs. Perhaps I should say &#39;reimagining&#39; to 
appease the re-word pedants; despite the opening

premise of coming to a 1920&#39;s Louisiana mansion in 
search of a missing relative and getting embroiled

in unspecifically Lovecrafty shenanigans, Alone in 
the Dark 2024 goes in entirely its own direction

after that, which again is probably for the best, 
but the direction they&#39;ve picked is the crowded

eight-lane highway signposted &quot;The Usual Resident 
Evil 4 Thing.&quot; So you know what that means,

over the shoulder aiming and contextual button 
prompts up the bum. Which is practically how

close some of them have to be before Edward Carnby 
will finally consent to press A on them. Oh yeah,

you also have the original game&#39;s choice between 
two protagonists, Emily Hartwood or Edward Carnby,

Edward Carnby being just about the only 
consistent presence between Alone in the

Dark games, I mean, some of them aren&#39;t 
even about being alone, or in the dark.

Edward&#39;s also as consistent as he&#39;s ever been, 
in that he&#39;s a white dude. Disappointingly he

doesn&#39;t have that razor sharp moustache he had in 
the original that meant he couldn&#39;t go swimming

without also going spear fishing, but y&#39;know, 
reimagining. He and Emily show up to Derceto

Mansion to find that it&#39;s gone all Shutter 
Island on us and is now an asylum for a load

of suspect Depression-era weirdos, who proceed 
to suspiciously weird all over us as we search

for Emily&#39;s uncle, who it turns out has been using 
Lovecrafty magic to create weird pocket dimensions

based on his memories, possibly so the orderlies 
couldn&#39;t catch him having a sneaky wank, and Emily

and Edward keep finding themselves slipping into 
these places to have fights with generic gribbly

monsters that probably represent the dude&#39;s sneaky 
wank-based paranoia or something. But Emily and

Edward adjust like champs, there&#39;s a cutscene 
where Emily returns to reality after fending off

hostile wank monsters in hallucinatory New Orleans 
and immediately starts awkwardly flirting with a

passing convenient flapper. The protagonists 
are consistently a bit ahead of me, story-wise.

They&#39;ll be talking to the doctor character 
who couldn&#39;t be more obviously villainous if

he had a Fu Manchu moustache with a strangled 
kitten dangling off both ends and Edward&#39;ll be

like &quot;But what has this got to do with the 
convent?&quot; And I&#39;ll be like &quot;What convent?

Where&#39;s this convent shit coming from?&quot; Turns 
out that it was mentioned in one of the random

documents I&#39;d picked up earlier. Bold of you 
to assume I actually read those, Edward. Sorry,

but I&#39;m typically motivated more to explore the 
intriguing horror mansion than I am to sit in a

quiet corner reading the fucking newspaper. Show, 
don&#39;t tell, as the exasperated stage manager said

to the socially oblivious can-can dancer. But 
let&#39;s stop flicking at the earlobes and really dig

that Q-tip in. There&#39;s only one fairly important 
question hanging over a horror game - is Alone In

The Dark 2024 scary? No, not really. It&#39;s fallen 
into the Silent Hill: Shattered Memories trap - if

monsters only show up in certain parts of 
the game then we can skip merrily through

the rest of it without a concern in our hearts, 
gleefully flinging unread documents in our wake.

When you are in combat it isn&#39;t terribly 
inspired: there&#39;s a pistol, there&#39;s a shotgun,

there&#39;s a drum magazine tommy gun that kinda 
breaks the difficulty but what can you do,

the tommy gun is to depression-era settings what 
Harley Quinn is to any DC universe property:

people complain if you DON&#39;T put it in. There&#39;s 
also melee combat but some gleeful imp replaced

all the weapons with breadsticks that snap after 
two or three hits, although the protagonist&#39;s

technique probably doesn&#39;t help as they tend to 
wave the things around like they&#39;re teaching a

Dalek how to swing dance. There&#39;s also contextual 
throwable items in the environment which are

occasionally molotovs and ostensibly light enemies 
on fire although it looks more like they&#39;ve just

put on delightful little orange ballet tutus and 
are really efficient for making you nostalgic for

the really good fire physics from the identically 
titled game from fifteen fucking years ago,

but most of the time the throwables bounce 
off enemies like crumpled paper balls off

a stupid dog&#39;s face. The game tells you to 
use them as distractions so you can stealth

past the dudes. But I know stealth games and 
you, Alone in the Dark, are no stealth game.

Sneaking past dudes just means having to deal 
with them later when you get spotted further

down the line and get swarmed by everything on 
the map like you&#39;re the last chocolate biscuit at

a Weightwatchers meeting. And besides, ooh yeah, 
that&#39;s a real terrifying monster you&#39;ve got there,

Mr. Horror Game, staring idiotically at a bit of 
wall because I just hefted an egg carton at it.

You&#39;re gonna have to do better than that to stand 
out, what else you got? &quot;Do you like puzzles,

Yahtz?&quot; Sure do! &quot;Do you like jigsaw puzzles with 
a maximum of 9 pieces?&quot; Oh yes! They keep my four

year old occupied while I do grown up things like 
crosswords and rewiring electronics. Don&#39;t suppose

you&#39;ve got anything like that. &quot;Uh... no, it&#39;s 
mostly baby jigsaws. But you have to rotate the

pieces sometimes.&quot; Yeah, I think the word I&#39;m 
going to write on the sign nailed to the top of

Alone in the Dark 2024&#39;s cross is &quot;uninspired.&quot; 
Uninspired combat, uninspired puzzles, a plot

that&#39;s all over the place and characters I just 
can&#39;t get in sync with, and not just because I&#39;ve

never worn a trilby or unironically addressed 
a woman as &quot;dame.&quot; What? That&#39;s a fedora!
